Policy Text: PBS Procurement Instructional Bulletin 21-04 GSA Public Buildings Service MEMORANDUM FOR PUBLIC BUILDINGS SERVICE REGIONAL COMMISSIONERS ACQUISITION DIRECTORS FROM: SUBJECT 1. Purpose TRACY M. MARCINOWSKI ASSISTANT COMMISSIONER OFFICE OF ACQUISITION MANAGEMENT (PQ) Senior Procurement Executive (SPE) Review and Approval Process The purpose of this Procurement Instructional Bulletin (PIB) is to provide guidance on requesting Senior Procurement Executive (SPE) review and approval of certain contract actions. 2. Background This PIB supplements the policies and procedures concerning acquisitions and contract actions requiring SPE review or approval in accordance with General Services Administration Acquisition Manual (GSAM) 504.7104 and the guidance provided on the Office of Government-wide Policy (OGP) SPE Review and Approval page on InSite . The below are common examples where SPE approval is required: i. Class Deviations - Class deviations to the Federal Acquisition Regulation (FAR) or General Services Administration Acquisition Regulation (GSAR) at any dollar value are approved by the SPE, unless otherwise delegated, in accordance with GSAM 501.404. ii. Consolidation and Bundling Determinations - The SPE is required to approve all consolidation, bundling, and substantial bundling analyses in accordance with GSAR 507.107. See the Acquisition Portal Consolidation and Bundling page for additional details. 1800 F Street, NW Washington, DC 20405-0002 www.gsa.gov iii. Justifications for Other Than Full and Open Competition (FAR 6.304(a)(4)), Justifications for an Exception to Fair Opportunity (FAR 16.505(b)(2)(ii)(C)(4)), and Limited Sources Justifications (FAR 8.405-6(d)(4)) - Justifications for a proposed procurement over $75 million are approved by the SPE, unless otherwise excepted. iv. Cost Accounting Standards (CAS) Waiver - CAS waiver requests are submitted to the SPE, in accordance with GSAM 530.201-5. 3. Effective Date This PIB is effective on the date signed. 4. Cancelation Date This PIB will remain in effect until canceled. 5. Applicability This PIB applies to all FAR-based Public Buildings Service (PBS) acquisitions. 6. References GSAM 504.7104 Office of Government-wide Policy (OGP) SPE Review and Approval page on InSite 7. Exemptions Acquisitions conducted under FAR Part 18, Emergency Acquisitions. 8. Instructions and Procedures 8.A. SPE Acquisition Review Briefing (ARB) Request 8.A.1 When To Conduct an ARB An ARB with the SPE must be conducted as early in the acquisition life cycle as possible (e.g. market research phase) to identify any issues up front and to help expedite the final approval . The ARB should occur prior to the preparation of the document that will need the SPE s signature. 8.A.2 Preparing for the ARB The ARBs should focus on high-level considerations, covering the topics identified at GSAM 504.7102(d). The contracting activity shall prepare slides in advance in Google slides using this ARB Template . Do not edit the template. Instead, make a copy of the template. Since the slides will be shared with the SPE in advance, the contracting activity should not expect to read the slides during the ARB. Rather, the contracting activity should expect a dialogue with the SPE. PIB 21-04 2 The contracting activity shall mark presentation slides with source selection information in accordance with FAR Subpart 3.104-4(c). The ARB will be scheduled for one hour . Attachment 1 identifies the individuals who will be invited to the ARB. 8.A.3 How to Request an ARB When a contracting activity has identified the need for an ARB with the SPE, they shall submit an email to the PBS Office of Acquisition Management (OAM) Policy and Programs Division (PQA), at pbsoampolicy@gsa.gov with the following information: (1) Description of the need for SPE involvement (e.g., SPE approval of a consolidation determination); (2) Description of the requirement, including key milestones (e.g., anticipated solicitation date, anticipated award date); (3) Suggested date(s) of acquisition review(s); (4) ARB slides ( in Google slides using this ARB Template ); (5) A list of regional attendees (see Attachment 1 for attendee list); and (6) Any other important information. Requests to OAM for an ARB with the SPE should be made at least fifteen business days prior to the suggested date of the ARB. Within five business days of receiving the request, OAM will:   Send an email to spe.request@gsa.gov with the information contained in GSAM 504.7104(b);   Send out a calendar invitation for the ARB to all required and optional attendees; and   Coordinate with Central Office OGC on review and comments, and provide any comments to the contracting activity. All of the information provided, including the slides, will be reviewed by OAM prior to sharing with the SPE. Once any comments have been addressed, OAM will add the slides and any draft documents to the calendar invitation. Draft documents are not required for an ARB, and any draft documents provided will still need to go through a formal SPE review and approval process after the ARB. PIB 21-04 3 8.A.4 Special Considerations for Consolidation and Bundling Determinations Consolidation and Bundling Determinations require an understanding of the consolidation and bundling process, understanding of a  new requirement  , 1 in-depth market research, early coordination with the Office of Small and Disadvantaged Business Utilization (OSDBU), and an analysis of cost savings prior to the scheduling of an ARB with the SPE. See Attachment 2 for best practices for consolidation and bundling determination reviews. 8.A.5 ARB Summary Within five business days after the ARB, OAM will provide a summary to all attendees that will include any recommendations and action items. 8.B. SPE Final Document Approval 8.B.1 OAM Routing Following the SPE ARB, after a contracting activity has prepared the document requiring SPE review and received all regional-level concurrences, they shall submit the document for OAM review to pbsoampolicy@gsa.gov with the following information: (1) Description of the requirement, action required, and due date; (2) Separate the signature page from the rest of the document. This will allow changes to be made without having to go through the entire signature approval process again; Unless there are significant changes ( e.g., changes that materially impact the acquisition strategy and opportunities relating to small business, competition, category management) , documents do not always have to be rerouted for signature. Provided as an attachment to this PIB is a document routing template that can be modified and used, as appropriate; however, a signed pdf should be submitted; 1 To determine if the expansion or modification of an existing requirement would be considered a  new  requirement, several factors must be considered: (1) Whether the scope has changed significantly, requiring different types of work or capabilities; (2) Whether the magnitude or value of the requirement has changed significantly, such as greater than 25 percent; (3) Whether the end use of the requirement has changed; and (4) Whether the requirements have meaningfully changed, such as new technical specifications, different delivery schedules, or new performance locations.  New  requirements would not have been previously provided and would not meet the definition of consolidation or bundling; therefore, new requirements do not require a written determination. See Consolidation and Bundling FAQs for additional information. PIB 21-04 4 (3) Share the main body of the document as a Google document to enable reviewers to easily enter comments or suggested edits (or utilize a comment matrix if more practical for the circumstances and document type(s)) ; (4) Supporting attachments, if applicable; (5) Any other important information. OAM will coordinate with the Central Office OGC on review and comments, and will provide any comments to the contracting activity within five business days of receiving the information. Once comments from OAM/OGC have been addressed (if any), OAM/OGC will sign the document and OAM will return the document to the contracting activity. 8.B.2 SPE Routing The contracting activity shall follow the procedures in GSAM 504.7104(c) and OGP s Step 2 - Final Document Approval and submit the required email to the SPE at spe.request@gsa.gov and, if necessary, OSDBU at osdbu_review_concurrence@gsa.gov with a carbon copy to OAM at pbsoampolicy@gsa.gov . 9. Point of Contact Any questions regarding the PIB may be addressed to the PBS Office of Acquisition Management at pbsoampolicy@gsa.gov . 10. Attachments   Attachment 1, ARB Invitee List   Attachment 2, Best practices for consolidation and bundling determination reviews   ARB Template (Google Slides)   Document Routing Template (Google Docs) PIB 21-04 5

## Policy Analysis: PBS Procurement Instructional Bulletin 21-04 and Executive Order 14154

### 1. Brief Summary of the Policy Text

PBS Procurement Instructional Bulletin 21-04 establishes guidance for GSA Public Buildings Service regarding when Senior Procurement Executive (SPE) review and approval is required for certain contract actions. The policy outlines four main categories requiring SPE approval:
- Class deviations from Federal Acquisition Regulation (FAR) or GSA Acquisition Regulation (GSAR)
- Consolidation and bundling determinations
- Justifications for other than full and open competition over $75 million
- Cost Accounting Standards (CAS) waiver requests

This is an internal procurement process document that governs approval workflows within GSA's acquisition system.

### 2. Brief Summary of the Executive Order Text

Executive Order 14154, "Unleashing American Energy," establishes a policy framework to promote energy exploration and production on federal lands and waters. The order aims to:
- Encourage energy exploration and production on federal lands and the Outer Continental Shelf
- Position the U.S. as a leading producer of non-fuel minerals, including rare earth minerals
- Protect national and economic security through reliable energy supply
- Remove burdensome regulations that impede energy resource development

The order emphasizes reducing regulatory barriers to energy development and strengthening American energy independence.

### 3. Detailed Explanation of Executive Order Applicability

This executive order does **not directly apply** to PBS Procurement Instructional Bulletin 21-04. Here's why:

**Scope Mismatch**: The PIB governs internal GSA procurement approval processes, while the executive order focuses on energy policy and resource development regulations. The PIB is a procedural document about acquisition workflows, not a substantive regulation affecting energy development.

**Different Regulatory Domains**: The executive order targets regulations that "impede energy development" and affect energy exploration, production, and mineral extraction. The PIB addresses procurement approval authorities within GSA's Public Buildings Service, which primarily deals with federal building construction, renovation, and management services.

**No Direct Energy Development Impact**: The SPE approval processes outlined in the PIB (class deviations, bundling determinations, competition justifications, and CAS waivers) are standard procurement procedures that do not specifically regulate or restrict energy-related activities.

**Procedural vs. Substantive**: The PIB is a procedural instruction that governs internal approval workflows, while the executive order targets substantive regulations that create barriers to energy development.

### 4. Next Steps to Achieve Compliance

Since this policy is not affected by the executive order, no compliance actions are required. However, as a prudent measure:

- **Monitor for Future Guidance**: Watch for any GSA-specific implementation guidance related to the executive order that might affect procurement processes for energy-related projects.
- **Review Energy-Related Procurements**: When the SPE review process is applied to energy sector contracts, ensure alignment with the administration's energy policy objectives.
- **Stay Alert for Policy Updates**: Be prepared to modify approval processes if future directives specifically address procurement procedures for energy development projects.

**Final Determination: [Not Affected]**

Throughout this document this act will be referred to as the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law (BIL). The relevant enacted language from the Act is as follows:  For an additional amount to be deposited in the  Federal Buildings Fund , $3,418,008,000, to remain available until expended, for construction and acquisition, and repairs and alterations of border stations and land ports of entry, of which no more than $250,000,000 shall be for Program Contingency and Operational Support for necessary expenses for projects funded under this heading, including, moving governmental agencies (including space alterations and adjustments, and telecommunications relocation expenses) in connection with the assignment, allocation and transfer of space, leasing of temporary space, and building operations, of which  (1) $2,527,808,000 shall be for projects on the U.S. Customs and Border Protection five-year plan; ## Policy Analysis Summary

### 1. Brief Summary of Policy Text
The GSA memorandum from September 28, 2022, provides financial execution guidance for the $3.4 billion appropriated to the Federal Buildings Fund (FBF) through the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (IIJA/Bipartisan Infrastructure Law). The policy establishes specific tracking requirements for BIL program support costs, including new accounting codes, labor coding procedures, and timecard tracking for administrative hours spent on BIL activities. It primarily focuses on financial management and administrative procedures for infrastructure funding.

### 2. Brief Summary of Executive Order Text
Executive Order 14154, "Unleashing American Energy," issued January 20, 2025, establishes a policy framework to promote energy exploration and production on federal lands and waters. The order aims to reduce regulatory burdens on energy development, encourage energy exploration including on the Outer Continental Shelf, establish the U.S. as a leading producer of non-fuel minerals including rare earth minerals, and strengthen national security through energy independence. The order emphasizes removing "burdensome and ideologically motivated regulations" that have impeded energy resource development.

### 3. Detailed Explanation of Executive Order Applicability
This executive order does **not directly apply** to the GSA policy for the following reasons:

**Scope Differences:**
- The GSA memorandum is purely administrative, focusing on financial tracking and accounting procedures for infrastructure investments
- The executive order targets energy policy and regulatory frameworks affecting energy exploration and production

**Subject Matter Distinction:**
- The GSA policy addresses internal financial management systems for the Federal Buildings Fund
- The executive order addresses substantive energy policy and resource development on federal lands

**Regulatory vs. Administrative Functions:**
- The executive order targets regulatory burdens that impede energy development
- The GSA memorandum establishes internal accounting procedures rather than external regulations

**Infrastructure vs. Energy Focus:**
- While both documents relate to federal activities, the infrastructure investments covered by the GSA policy (federal buildings, facilities) are distinct from the energy exploration and production activities emphasized in the executive order

Since the executive order does not directly impact this financial tracking policy, no immediate compliance actions are required. However, GSA should:

**Monitoring Actions:**
- Monitor for future executive orders or agency guidance that may specifically address infrastructure spending priorities
- Review any BIL-funded projects to ensure they align with the administration's energy policy objectives where applicable

**Coordination Considerations:**
- If any BIL-funded federal building projects include energy-related components (solar installations, energy efficiency upgrades), ensure coordination with the new energy policy framework
- Maintain awareness of how the administration's energy priorities might influence future infrastructure investment decisions

**Final Determination: [Not Affected]**
